comments.commentBody: This opinion piece is bull.  The Ryan plans to distribute health care to the states are intended to markedly reduce health insurance coverage, below where it was before the ACA. Think: Impoverishing more people and taking benefits from relatively poor people is an effort to increase voters for cruel government action and for an increasing Trumputinian autocracy.  It's not always easy for people to understand WHY they are worse off, and so such adverse changes help make people more extreme, reactionary voters.

Here's the thing on Walker's concept of states' rights: It totally conflicts with his (and his leader and their supporters) concept of running the country like a business. Businessmen know that mergers and acquisitions reduce costs by consolidating and eliminating duplicated positions. The federal government is the result of a merger of the states. However, unlike a business, those at the top are not supposed to benefit from those consolidations, and with attentive oversight ALL the people will benefit.
The same concept can be used with regard to unions, which Walker and other "right to worker's" tout as the bane of our existence. Union jobs are the centerpiece of our middle class, and union busting removes the consolidating benefits of the middle class union jobs, which results in lower wages, pushing them into borderline poverty.
California would gladly keep the tax revenue it collects on behalf of the Federal government considering we only get about 70 cents on the dollar back in federal funds.

Scott Walker neglected to include another of his 'soul mates' among Conservative governors: Kansas Governor Sam Brownback. With this Conservative template in place, we can see the outcome of these principles in action: bankrupted states, depleted educational systems, and damage done to the most vulnerable of citizens.

What Walker also neglects to do is to be honest about the legitimate roles of government and markets in providing health care to Americans. The 'state rights' argument is really a ruse to cripple the government regulatory and protective functions that most Americans actually want.

This is the guy who was the first to crumble in the Keystone Kops crucible of the 2016 GOP presidential primary campaign. He's never been able to take the heat, retreating into his Koch-fueled world of tired Tea Party platitudes and class warfare, and somehow he had sold the bill of goods to Wisconsans well enough to remain relevant in his own mind. He's a tired joke and while I salute the Times for giving him the precious ink and pixels to spout his "stand strong" rhetoric, a closer reading between the lines reveals just another weak demagogue echoing the paranoid, monosyllabic "billionaire" who now sullies the White House.

One would think that a man with such grand ideas would righteously be President of these United States.  But alas, not Walker, he was an early casualty of the 2016 primaries of the Republican Party.  He is no friend of the working man, to be sure.  He eliminated collective bargaining for public employees, except for cops and firefighters.  In his state and others those people tend to vote Republican for reasons I will never understand.  As a Firefighter Union president in the 70s and 80s I can assure Mr. Walker and anyone else who would care to listen that the only thing that stood in the way of a better life for firefighters and cops were Republicans from city councils to the national government.  They never were and never will be supporters of the middle class and the workers who made the middle class.  What do they say about a leopard?

It's ironic Gov. Walker cites Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa on collective bargaining at the same time they reject Iowa's model on legislative redistricting. Iowa has a public, transparent nonpartisan process, Wisconsin has a partisan process formulated in secret behind closed doors.
It's also ironic Walker supports "states rights" while he and the Wisconsin Republican leadership propose legislation for state control over municipal authorities.
Meanwhile, he and legislators argue how to pay for badly needed transportation maintenance and infrastructure improvements. Walker proposed borrowing more money while rejecting some common-sense suggestions, including various fee increases or an inflation-adjusted fuel tax at the pump. State estimates on a number of Wisconsin highway contracts have been unrealistically low, with flawed methodology.
I have lived and worked in Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin. As other readers have pointed out in their comments, Minnesota has flourished while Wisconsin has withered. In Iowa, governance is more transparent and pragmatic than Wisconsin. Models of successful and constructive governance are available but Walker has chose to ignore them.

What a crock. If you want to distract voters from the real issues start hollering "State's Rights". It distracted some during the Civil War who didn't want to admit it was all about slavery.
I hope the people of Wisconsin survive Walker.

I don't know where to start in untangling this word salad. Navigating unspoken agendas, half truths, lies, ignorance and twisted world views, is exhausting. I'm sorely tempted to give up, which is exactly what these fools are hoping. I'll keep slogging, right along with the heroic journalists who are doing their best to get behind the smoke and turn the mirrors upon the circus acts.

Exactly the same thing happened in Louisiana under Rep. Governor Jindal 9 years ago.  We are still having budget short-falls after he had depleted all the rainy day funds and state reserves.  The current Rep. dominated legislature still has their heads in the sand.

Walker may be evermore unhinged than Trump.
Scary.
You may want to take that back after the early am Trump tweets today...
Words from the most un- and anti-democratically elected Governor in the United States.
It is big corporate money that has too much control over the government, not public sector unions. Of course, you know that very well.

"Explain that the centerpiece in the Republican agenda — returning authority to the states — is the best solution to our nation’s problems."

State authority is one of this country's most-serious problems, because it allows states to maintain the status quo -- which usually means socially, politically, and economically oppressing minorities, and pandering to the wealthy.

If the NYT is trying to make Scott Walker -- a widely disrespected governor -- look like a fool, it's done a good job by publishing this piece.
The main reason for states rights and similar efforts to devolve government is that it reduces the cost of bribery.

“Those who profess to favor freedom and yet depreciate agitation, are people who want crops without ploughing the ground; they want rain without thunder and lightning; they want the ocean without the roar of its many waters. The struggle may be a moral one, or it may be a physical one, or it may be both. But it must be a struggle. Power concedes nothing without a demand. It never did and it never will.”
― Frederick Douglass

Scott, how did Sam Brownback's conservative movement work in Kansas? Just wondering, because Kansas has had a one-party system in place for some years and been working tirelessly to enact your low-tax, smaller government utopia.

The women's march in WI was actually the largest march, per capital, that occured that day. It was massive! And totally peaceful.

Probably it worries Walker that so many, women, men, children showed up that tens of thousands could not even park their vehicles or arrive at the march!

People in WI already know what it feels like to be disenfranchised via gerrymandering. They know what it feels like to live under a virtual dictatorship. They will fight, tooth and nail, against trump, walke and any who seek to deprive them of justice and equality.

Walker may lack even his college degree. But he sees the size of protests, the handwriting on the wall of being as underwater as trump.

Stand strong against the will of the people!
That's what the GOP sees as Democracy.
Excellent. I never protested before. But I'm also fired up. And frightened. Great comment! Thank you.

Mr. Walker, Your stance comes across as an "Achtung: My way whether correct or incorrect" stance; one that implies threat as well as an authoritarian attitude. Why do you express your self in this manner?
I'm pretty sure we fought a war about this issue and Mr. Walker's state's rights position lost.

Debbie:
Printing this snake oil is the right thing to do. In this piece Scott Walker has clearly stated what he stands for, and made it clear why the Republican agenda, if implemented, will set the country back at least fifty years, and why it must be stopped. I think the expression is "Hoist by his own petard".
Scott Walker, the sniveling coward who talked on the phone about taking a baseball bat to his constituents.  Who bothers listening to this waste of space?

Mr. Walker is out of his level of competence lecturing on how to solve national problems.  Cutting costs and saving taxes within the state of Wisconsin is not the same as Washington making vast cuts in grants to the states, EPA for example, and then spending the savings on huge increases in the military budget.  Or even running big deficits instead.  If you want state rights, then send all of the saved money back to the states.  If you want laws to reflect state rights then don't be selective about which regulations you want to shove down states throats and which regulations you want to cut.

Well I'm glad Gov Walker feels that way! Because for many states on the coasts in the northeast and west, we have been paying $2 in federal taxes and only getting $1 back.

Most of the states which overwhelmingly voted for him get $2 to $3 back for every $1 they pay. These "handouts" should immediately end and these states, as Gov Walker seems to suggest, should fend for themselves.

I am sure he is not suggesting that they should receive the same amounts from the fed, but just have total discretion about how to spend it, right? And that includes Obama Care. Let's shape that debate Gov, because I'm tired of paying money to Trump territory voters but have little say in how they spend it.
